questiontext.text: Associate the following physical quantities with their definition.

answer.text: Rate at which radiation is emitted from a surface per unit area.
Rate at which radiation is incident upon a surface per unit area.
Rate at which radiation leaves a surface per unit area.

subquestion.text: Net radiative flux : \( q^{''}_{rad}=J-G \).

answer.text: Net rate of radiation leaving a surface per unit area.

questiontext.text:
The red surface is heated to the temperature Th and radiates energy to surfaces A and B.
Which surface receives the most energy per unit of time from the heated surface ?

answer.text: Surface A.
Surface B.
They receive the same amount of energy per unit of time.
Not enough information to answer. depend de la propriété

questiontext.text:
A student wishes to calculate the rate at which radiation emitted by the surface A1 is intercepted by the surface A2.
The student claims that this rate is equal to :

\( q=I\times A_1 \times \dfrac{A_2\cos\theta_2}{L^2} \),

where \( I \) is the directional radiation intensity. Do you think that :

generalfeedback.text:
The student is wrong : both surfaces must be projected. Here surface A1 appear as if its normal was directed towards surface A2 ,which is not the case. 

\( q=I\times A_1 \cos{\theta_1}\times \dfrac{A_2\cos\theta_2}{L^2} \),

The radiative intensity is defined as the rate at which radiant energy is emitted at the wavelength \( \lambda \) in the \( (\theta,\phi) \) direction, per unit area of the emitting surface normal to this direction, per unit solid angle about this direction, and per unit wavelength interval \( \text{d}\lambda \) about \( \lambda \).

answer.text: The student is right
The student is wrong

questiontext.text:
The red surface is heated to the temperature Th and radiates energy to surfaces A and B.
Suppose that the spectral intensity at 500 nm collected by surface A is twice the spectral intensity collected by surface B.
What can you say about the spectral intensity at 1000 nm ?

answer.text: The spectral intensity at 1000 nm collected by surface A is twice the spectral intensity collected by surface B.
The spectral intensity at 1000 nm collected by surface A is equal to the spectral intensity collected by surface B.
The spectral intensity at 1000 nm collected by surface A is half the spectral intensity collected by surface B.
Not enough information to answer.

questiontext.text:
A student wishes to calculate the solid angle at which a disc of radius R is seen from a point O when facing it from a distance L.
The student claims that the solid angle is equal to the area of the disc divided by the distance L squared.
Do you think that :

answer.text: The student is right.
The student is wrong.

questiontext.text:
The rate at which radiation is emitted (in watts) by a body depends on :
(Check all the possible answers.)

generalfeedback.text: The rate at which radiation is emitted (in watts) by a body depends on the surface properties (material used, surface finish), its temperature and the area of the body surface : \( q_{rad}=A\varepsilon\sigma(T_s^4-T_{sur}^4) \).

answer.text: The surface properties (material used, surface finish)
Its temperature
The area of the body surface

questiontext.text: Check the sentences that you consider to be correct. (There are 5 correct answers)

answer.text: Radiation is a transfer of energy at a distance, without physical contact.
Emission of thermal radiation is associated to thermally excited conditions within the matter.
The amount of energy emitted by a radiating object is lower the higher its temperature.
The colour of a radiating object varies according to its temperature.
The equilibrium temperature of an object depends solely on the radiation it receives from its environment.
An object placed in an environment receives thermal radiation from all the materials around it that are in visual contact with it.
If an object is colder than its surroundings, it emits less radiation than it receives, and therefore tends to heat up.
Only warm bodies emit radiation.

questiontext.text:
A cup of coffee placed on a table in a room cools by :
(Check all the possible answers.)

generalfeedback.text: A cup of coffee placed on a table in a room will cool by conduction with the table and surrounding air, by convection (free or forced depending on the flow conditions) and by radiation with surrounding walls and objects in the room.

answer.text: Conduction
Convection
Radiation

questiontext.text:
An object is at constant temperature in a vacuum chamber.
What heat transfers is it subject to ?
(Check all the possible answers.)

generalfeedback.text: An object at constant temperature in a vacuum chamber is only subject to heat transfer by radiation with surrounding walls. It is assumed that there is no contact with the chamber, thus no conduction effects.

answer.text: Conduction
Convection
Radiation

questiontext.text: The electromagnetic radiation of a body at room temperature is mainly in the range of :

answer.text: Visible light
Infrared light
Ultraviolet light

questiontext.text: A fire breaks out on a wall near a person. How long will it take for the heat flux to reach the person ?

generalfeedback.text: Whether radiation is viewed as the propagation of electromagnetic waves or photons, it travels at the speed of light. Thus the person will notice heat transfer by radiation from the fire almost instantly. The time scale associated with radiative heat transfer is much smaller than the time scale associated with conduction or convection.

answer.text: Almost instantly
~ 1 min
~ 1 h

questiontext.text:
The red surface is heated to the temperature Th and radiates energy to surfaces A and B of different area.

Complete the following sentence.

The solid angle subtended by the surface A is ______ ___ the solid angle subtended by the surface B as viewed from the heated surface.

generalfeedback.text: The solid angle subtended by the surface A is smaller than the solid angle subtended by the surface B as viewed from the heated surface. This is because surface A is smaller than surface B (all other things being equal).

answer.text: Larger than
Equal to
Smaller than
Not enough information to answer

questiontext.text:
On which parameters does the solid angle subtended by any surface as seen from an observer depend ?
(Check all the possible answers.)

answer.text: The distance between the surface and the observer.
The area of the surface.
The surface inclination.

questiontext.text:
The red surface is heated to the temperature Th  and radiates energy to surfaces A and B of equal area.

Complete the following sentence.

The solid angle subtended by the surface A is ______ ___ the solid angle subtended by the surface B as viewed from the heated surface.

generalfeedback.text: The solid angle subtended by the surface A is equal to the solid angle subtended by the surface B as viewed from the heated surface. This is because both surfaces occupy the same area as viewed from a point on the heated surface. On the other hand, the solid angle subtended by the heated surface is larger when viewed from surface A than when viewed from surface B.

answer.text: Larger than
Equal to
Smaller than
Not enough information to answer

questiontext.text:
The red surface is heated to the temperature Th and radiates energy to surfaces A and B of equal area.

Complete the following sentence.

The solid angle subtended by the heated surface is:

generalfeedback.text: The solid angle subtended by the heated surface is larger when viewed from surface A than when viewed from surface B. This is because surface A is the nearest to the heated surface (all other things being equal). You can see this my making the surfaces closer and closer : at some point, they will occupy the all hemisphere.

answer.text: Larger when viewed from surface A than from surface B
Larger when viewed from surface B than from surface A
Equal in both cases
Not enough information to answer

questiontext.text:
The red surface is heated to the temperature Th and radiates energy to surfaces A and B.
Which of the following sentences do you consider to be correct ?

answer.text: The solid angle subtended by the heated surface is bigger when viewed from surface A than when viewed from surface B.
The solid angle subtended by the heated surface is equal when viewed from surface A and when viewed from surface B.
The solid angle subtended by the heated surface is smaller when viewed from surface A than when viewed from surface B.

questiontext.text:
A small surface \( A \) is located at a large distance \( L \) from an observer. 
The surface is tilted as shown on the figure. A student claims that the solid angle subtended by the surface as viewed from the observer is equal to :

\( \omega=\dfrac{A}{L^2} \)

Do you think that :

generalfeedback.text:
The student is wrong : it is the projected surface that matters here. The cosine of the angle between the normal and the direction from the surface to the observer must appear. 

\( \omega=\dfrac{A\cos{\theta}}{L^2} \)

Moreover, if the surface cannot be considered small and far from the observer, an integration of \( \text{d}\omega \) must be performed.

answer.text: The student is right
The student is wrong

questiontext.text:
A small surface \( A \) or area 0.2 m2 is located at a distance \( L =\) 2.0 m from an observer.
The surface is tilted by an angle \( \theta = \pi/3 \) as shown below.
What is the solid angle subtended by the surface as viewed from the observer ?
